background_description: The background consists of a dense network of a Muricella gorgonian coral. It features pale, off-white or light grey branching stems, which are heavily covered with numerous small, spherical, bright reddish-orange polyps. There are dark, out-of-focus areas in the background, likely the surrounding deep water.
camouflage_type: Color blending / Pattern matching / Shape disruption
explanation: The Pygmy Seahorse (Hippocampus bargibanti) in this image exhibits exceptional camouflage. Its body coloration perfectly matches the pinkish-red polyps and the pale, off-white branches of the Muricella gorgonian coral it inhabits. Furthermore, its skin is covered in bulbous, wart-like tubercles that precisely mimic the size, shape, and distribution of the coral's polyps. This combination of color blending, pattern matching, and shape disruption makes the seahorse virtually indistinguishable from its coral host, effectively breaking up its outline and allowing it to blend seamlessly into the environment. It is extremely difficult to spot without close inspection.
